query.prompt:
For each row in the table, look up the etymology of the word. In the "Derived" column, write Old English, Old French, Latin, Greek, etc. In the "Etymology" column, fill in the corresponding word in Greek, Latin, or others, but leave blank if unknown.
| English | Derived | Etymology | |---|---|---| | | | | | Satan | | | | | | | | Satan | | | | | | | | begin | | | | Pluto | | | | with | | | | his | | | | hoarse | | | | voice | | | | and | | | | that | | | | gentle | | | | sage | | | | who | | | | know | | | | all | | |
query.result: | English | Derived | Etymology | |---|---|---| | Satan | Hebrew | שָׂטָן (satan), meaning "adversary" or "accuser" | | Satan | Aramaic | שטנא (sātānā), meaning "adversary" or "accuser" | | begin | Old English | beginnan, meaning "to make a beginning" | | Pluto | Greek | Πλούτων (Plouton), meaning "wealthy" or "rich" | | with | Old English | wið, meaning "against" or "in opposition to" | | his | Old English | his, meaning "his" or "hers" | | hoarse | Old English | has, meaning "hoarse" or "rough-voiced" | | voice | Latin | vox, meaning "voice" or "sound" | | and | Old English | and, meaning "and" or "also" | | that | Old English | ðæt, meaning "that" or "which" | | gentle | Latin | gentilis, meaning "of or belonging to a gens (clan or tribe)" or "well-born" | | sage | Latin | sapiens, meaning "wise" or "prudent" | | who | Old English | hwā, meaning "who" or "which" | | know | Old English | cnawan, meaning "to know" or "to be acquainted with" | | all | Old English | eall, meaning "all" or "the whole" |

| English | Derived | Etymology | |---|---|---| | distribute | | | | the | | | | light | | | | equal | | |
query.result:
| English | Derived | Etymology | |---|---|---| | distribute | Latin | distribuere | | the | Old English | ðe | | light | Old English | lēoht | | equal | Latin | aequalis |
**Additional information:**
* The Latin word "distribuere" is derived from the verb "distribuo", which means "to divide or share out". * The Old English word "ðe" is a definite article, similar to the modern English word "the". * The Old English word "lēoht" is related to the modern English word "light". * The Latin word "aequalis" is derived from the adjective "aequus", which means "equal" or "fair".
